jparsec.graph.chartRendering

Class RenderSky

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.graph.chartRendering.RenderSky

  • public class RenderSky
extends java.lang.Object
    A class for sky rendering

    This class performs sky rendering operations. The first step is to configure the render process with the necessary input objects. Rendering is performed using a sequence of high precision ephemeris with very optimized algorithms, allowing to read, calculate, and accurately draw thousands of different kind of objects in a fraction of second for any given date and place.

    Stars are rendered after calculating their apparent positions. Limiting magnitude is 10.0, but only stars up to 6.5 will be drawn, unless the scale is above 10 px/degree. In this case the limiting magnitude will be 7.5. If the scale is above 20 px/degree, all the stars up to 10.0 (limiting magnitude of the catalog used, adapted from Sky2000 Master Catalog) will be drawn. If the limiting magnitude is fainter, then those stars will be drawn using UCAC4 catalog if Internet connection is available. It is not recommended to set a limiting magnitude fainter than 10, unless you really need it. The limiting magnitude for stars is customizable in one of the parameters of the SkyRenderElement object, if you prefer to permanently reduce the number of stars shown. The same happens with other objects like comets, asteroids, and deep sky objects, but if the scale is above 20 px/degree, then all the objects will be drawn, until the selected limiting magnitude for these objects, which is by default much bigger than the limiting magnitude for stars. So until 20 px/degree the same limiting magnitude (6.5 or 7.5) exist for every usual object, unless you select a lower value in the corresponding cases. Labels for deep sky objects are shown only for scales above 10 px/degree. The user may expect the possibility of showing deep sky objects with apparent magnitudes below 7.5 for scales below 20 px/degree. This can be achieved setting a given limiting magnitude for objects (>7.5), 10 for instance. In this case, every object up to 10.0 magnitude (or the selected value) will be visible, but not any other fainter than this. This allow showing more objects without making a mess in the image with too many ones. Of course, this is an important question that an hypothetical user should take into account depending on different considerations.

    In addition to comets and asteroids, trans-Neptunian objects (treated as asteroids), space probes, and artificial satellites are also supported. They will be drawn if the scale is above 10 px/degree, with no limiting magnitude considerations in space probes and artificial satellites. If an object is occulted, or any satellite is eclipsed, it will not be drawn. Comets and asteroids will be drawn if the reference time of orbital elements is less than a century away from the current time. Comet tails are shown as if they should be visible if they were extended up to 20 000 000 km. For space probes and artificial satellites, considerations about active times of the object are taken into account.

    This sky rendering class also works as a planet renderer. Planets are drawn as symbols when the disk is not visible, and in the same situation, the Sun, the Moon, space probes and artificial satellites are drawn as icons if textures are enabled.

    Labels for natural satellites are drawn only for fields of view below one degree. Apparent sizes of stars depends on magnitude, and are correlated with sizes of natural satellites when they are not resolved as discs.

    The circle representing the angular field of view of the instrument (telescope, objective) will be shown only if the field is below 50 degrees.

    Apparent sky can be rendered using horizontal coordinates and any projection type. If you want to occult the sky below the horizon you can set the proper field to false. Only in this case, the method will automatically correct elevation to apparent (refraction) and for depression of the horizon.

    For dates outside interval -3000 to +3000 in years, no Solar System object will be shown. There are no explicit limiting dates for sky rendering when the precession algorithm by Vondrak 2011 is used, but it is not recommended to go more than 100 000 years into the past or future.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)

    • Field Detail

      • ReportEphemToConsole

        public boolean ReportEphemToConsole
        True to report to console the results of the ephemerides of minor objects. True by default.

      • SaveObjectsToAllowSearch

        public boolean SaveObjectsToAllowSearch
        True (default value) to save visible objects to an array to later allow search and identification based on screen position. False will save memory.

      • FakeStarsForExternalGraphics

        public boolean FakeStarsForExternalGraphics
        True (default value) to render stars in fake (AWT) mode instead of using image textures when rendering is performed to external graphics. True allows to render stars in vector graphics (PDF output) and to reduce file size a lot.

      • render

        public SkyRenderElement render
        Sky render object that holds render parameters. It is hold here as public to simplyfy the access to underlying information, but be careful not to change it unless you later call to methods like forceUpdateFast() or resetLeyend(boolean).

      • planets

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Object> planets
        A list to hold rendered planets. Planetographic coordinates can be obtained after any render using this list.

      • leyendMargin

        public int leyendMargin

      • graphMarginX

        public int graphMarginX

      • graphMarginY

        public int graphMarginY

    • Method Detail

      • getRectangle

        public float[] getRectangle()
        Returns the internal rectagble of the rendering grid.
        Returns:
        An array with minimum x, minimum y, width, and height of the external rectangle.

      • isAllPosibleObjectsInNextFrame

        public boolean isAllPosibleObjectsInNextFrame()
        Returns if the drawing of all possible objects in a limited sky region is active.
        Returns:
        True or false.

      • toggleAllPosibleObjectsInNextFrame

        public boolean toggleAllPosibleObjectsInNextFrame()
        Toggles on/off the drawing of all possible objects in the next rendering up to a reasonable limiting magnitude based on field, loading into memory only the objects that will be visible on screen.

        This method has effect only in Android. The limiting magnitude for stars should be set to 6.5 exactly.

        Returns:
        True if the toggle was successful. In case of switching it on, next frame will contain more objects. false is returned when the field of view is too high (greater than 50 deg).

      • renderize

               throws java.lang.Exception
        Renderize the sky to another device.
        Parameters:
        gg - Graphics device.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Thrown if the calculation fails.

      • setStarsLimitingMagnitude

        public void setStarsLimitingMagnitude()
        This method should be called to update the limiting magnitude for stars when the field of view changes, or when you want to update the number of stars shown. Used internally, normally you shouldn't call this.

        width - Render width in pixels.

      • getSizeForAGivenMagnitude

        public static float getSizeForAGivenMagnitude(double mag,
                              double maglim,
                              int hugeFactor)
        Returns the radius of a star given its magnitude.
        Parameters:
        mag - Magnitude.
        maglim - Limiting magnitude.
        hugeFactor - A factor depending on the width in pixels of the rendering. 0 unles width >= 3000, incrementing by 1 in each 1000 px.
        Returns:
        Size in pixels.

      • getPositionInSelectedCoordinateSystem

        public static LocationElement getPositionInSelectedCoordinateSystem(LocationElement loc,
                                                    TimeElement time,
                                                    ObserverElement obs,
                                                    EphemerisElement eph,
                                                    SkyRenderElement sky,
                                                    boolean fast)
                                                             throws JPARSECException
        Returns the coordinates of certain equatorial position in the current selected coordinate system for sky projection.
        Parameters:
        loc - Equatorial (non-refracted) coordinates.
        time - Time object.
        obs - Observer object.
        eph - Ephemeris object.
        sky - Render object.
        fast - True for an approximate but faster calculation.
        Returns:
        Output coordinates. Same as input in the equatorial system.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the method fails.

      • calcStar

        public StarEphemElement calcStar(int my_star,
                        boolean fullDataAndPrecision)
                          throws JPARSECException
        Return ephemeris for a given star.
        Parameters:
        my_star - ID value for the star, retrieved with getClosestStarInScreenCoordinates(int, int, boolean).
        fullDataAndPrecision - True to return also rise, set, transit times.
        Returns:
        Ephemeris, or null if the star is not found.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getStar

        public StarElement getStar(int my_star)
                    throws JPARSECException
        Return star parameters for a given star. Proper motions are set to 0.
        Parameters:
        my_star - ID value for the star, retrieved with getClosestStarInScreenCoordinates(int, int, boolean).
        Returns:
        Star data.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • calcPlanet

        public EphemElement calcPlanet(Target.TARGET planet,
                      boolean alsoNonVisible,
                      boolean fullDataAndPrecision)
                        throws JPARSECException
        Return ephemeris for a given planet or natural satellite.
        Parameters:
        planet - ID value for the planet or natural satellite.
        alsoNonVisible - True to return ephemerides of the object even if it is not visible in the screen.
        fullDataAndPrecision - True to obtain results with maximum accuracy and including rise, set, transit times.
        Returns:
        Ephemeris, or null object if the target cannot be found in the screen. Null is never returned for natural satellites.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getClosestStarInScreenCoordinates

        public double[] getClosestStarInScreenCoordinates(int x,
                                         int y,
                                         boolean considerMagLim)
                                           throws JPARSECException
        Obtain ID constant of the closest star to certain screen position. For a valid output it is previously necessary to render the sky.
        Parameters:
        x - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        y - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        considerMagLim - True to consider the limiting magnitude to identify the star.
        Returns:
        A array with two values (null if no object is found):
        ID value (integer) of the star.
        Minimum distance to the input position in pixels.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

        public void setFieldOfView(double fov)
                    throws JPARSECException
        Changes the field of view. This option can be used to show a different FOV from the one automatically calculated based on the current selected telescope.
        Parameters:
        fov - Field of view in radians. Set to 0 to allow calculating it again using the current telescope.

      • getSkyPosition

        public float[] getSkyPosition(LocationElement loc,
                     boolean isEquatorial,
                     boolean checkScreen,
                     boolean correctForRefraction)
                       throws JPARSECException
        Returns the pixel position of a given location.
        Parameters:
        loc - Sky location.
        isEquatorial - True if input location is equatorial, false if it is given in the current selected coordinate system for rendering.
        checkScreen - True to check if the position is inside the visible screen or not. In case of true and the position is outside, null is returned.
        correctForRefraction - True to correct for refraction the input position. This only works in case of providing a location in the equatorial system, otherwise is ignored.
        Returns:
        The pixel position, or null if it cannot be obtained.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getPlanetographicPosition

        public LocationElement getPlanetographicPosition(double x,
                                        double y,
                                        int coordinate_system,
                                        boolean consider_satellites)
                                          throws JPARSECException
        Obtain planetographic, heliographic, selenographic, or satellitographic position for certain screen point. The default result will be always the position of the nearest body to the observer, if, for instance, one object is occulting/transiting any other. To avoid considering satellites in this proccess set the corresponding boolean to false.
        Parameters:
        x - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        y - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        coordinate_system - Reference coordinate system, only for giant planets: 1 (system I), 2 (system II), 3 (system III).
        consider_satellites - True to consider possible transiting satellites, false to ignore them.
        Returns:
        Corresponding position in the object, or null object if the position is outside any body rendered. The radius field of the location object will contain the index of the Target.TARGET body where this location was found.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getPlanetInScreenCoordinates

        public Target.TARGET getPlanetInScreenCoordinates(double x,
                                         double y,
                                         boolean consider_satellites,
                                         int minimumSize)
                                           throws JPARSECException
        Obtain ID constant of an object in certain screen position. For a valid output it is previously necessary to render the sky, and the object must be visible.
        Parameters:
        x - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        y - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        consider_satellites - True to consider possible transiting satellites, false to ignore them.
        minimumSize - Minimum size in pixels of the planet to consider it as identified for the input coordinates. Set to 0 to allow identifying planets event when their disks are almost invisible because of their minimum apparent sizes.
        Returns:
        ID value of the object, or Target.TARGET.NOT_A_PLANET if no object is found.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getClosestPlanetInScreenCoordinates

        public java.lang.Object[] getClosestPlanetInScreenCoordinates(double x,
                                                     double y,
                                                     boolean consider_satellites)
                                                       throws JPARSECException
        Obtain ID constant of the solar system object closest to certain screen position. For a valid output it is previously necessary to render the sky, and the object must be visible.
        Parameters:
        x - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        y - Horizontal position in the rendering in pixels.
        consider_satellites - True to consider possible transiting satellites, false to ignore them.
        Returns:
        A array with two values (null if no object is found):
        ID value (TARGET) of the object.
        Minimum distance (Double) to the input position in pixels.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getScreenCoordinatesOfPlanetographicPosition

        public float[] getScreenCoordinatesOfPlanetographicPosition(LocationElement locIn,
                                                   Target.TARGET body,
                                                   int coordinate_system,
                                                   boolean only_if_visible)
                                                     throws JPARSECException
        Obtain screen coordinates of a given planetographic, heliographic, selenographic, or satellitographic position in certain object. The scene must be rendered previously.
        Parameters:
        locIn - Planetographic/heliographic/selenographic coordinates on the object.
        body - ID value for the object, as defined in class Target.TARGET.
        coordinate_system - Reference coordinate system of input coordinates, only for giant planets: 1 (system I), 2 (system II), 3 (system III).
        only_if_visible - True for returning coordinates only if the input position is visible.
        Returns:
        Corresponding position in the screen, or Projection.INVALID_POSITION (null) if the object is not visible, of the position is not visible and only_if_visible is set to true.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • setJupiterGRSLongitude

        public void setJupiterGRSLongitude(double GRS_lon,
                          int system)
        Sets the longitude of Jupiter's Great Red Spot.

        Please note that the rendering will use the default value of the longitude of central meridian for rendering. This value is refered to System III for giant planets (rotation of the magnetic field), so the apparent rotation will not match that of the observed equatorial nor tropical belts in these planets. This function is intended to adjust specifically the apparent sight of Jupiter's disk.

        Parameters:
        GRS_lon - Observed longitude in radians. Typically obtained for a given date calling MainEvents.getJupiterGRSLongitude(double).
        system - System of coordinates of GRS_lon, 1, 2, or 3. Will be ussually 2, since the Great Red Spot is in the tropical belt (1 refers to equatorial belt, and 3 to the rotation of the magnetic field).

      • getJupiterGRSLongitude

        public double getJupiterGRSLongitude(int system)
        Returns the longitude of the GRS supposing that the longitude was updated using system 2 with setJupiterGRSLongitude(double, int).
        Parameters:
        system - The system on Jupiter, 1, 2, or 3.
        Returns:
        GRS longitude in radians.

      • resetLeyend

        public void resetLeyend(boolean alsoStars)
        Forces the leyend to be rendered again. Leyend is by default only drawn when something affecting it changes, like the limiting magnitude for stars when the sky is zoomed in/out, or the properties of nebula.
        Parameters:
        alsoStars - True to render again stars according to their sizes. False unless limiting magnitude or zoom changes.

      • dateChanged

        public void dateChanged(boolean forceAll)
        Clears ephemeris of minor bodies. This is necessary when the date changes moderately to calculate new ephemeris for these objects (comets, asteroids, transneptunian objects, probes, artificial satellites) when the next rendering is launch.
        Parameters:
        forceAll - True to force update of stars, constellations, milky way and nebula, and objects, false to do that only when required.

      • getClosestObjectData

        public java.lang.Object[] getClosestObjectData(int x,
                                      int y,
                                      boolean considerMagLim,
                                      boolean fullDataAndPrecision)
                                        throws JPARSECException
        Returns data for the object closest to certain screen coordinates. The data returned is an array of objects with the following information:

        - Integer ID constant for the object type. Constants defined in this class (enum OBJECT).
        - Integer array with the position in the screen x and y.
        - Information for the object. For stars, planets, natural or artificial satellites, comets, asteroids and probes an object of type EphemElement is returned, for deep sky objects a String array (with name, RA, DEC, magnitude, subtype, size in degrees, and comments), and for supernovae a String array (with name, RA, DEC, magnitude, and date of explosion).
        - Star additional data from catalogue (only for stars).

        Parameters:
        x - X position in pixels.
        y - Y position in pixels.
        considerMagLim - True to consider the limiting magnitude (recommended) to identify the object closest to the given position. This is done only for planets and stars.
        fullDataAndPrecision - True to return also rise, set, transit times for the closets object. Note this will be much slower in some cases.
        Returns:
        Object data, or null if no object is found or the position is outside the visible map.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getFullEphemerisOfMinorObject

        public EphemElement getFullEphemerisOfMinorObject(java.lang.String objName,
                                         RenderSky.OBJECT objType)
                                           throws JPARSECException
        Obtains full ephemeris (including rise, set, transit times) of a 'minor' body, which is any asteroid, comet, probe, transneptunian object, artificial satellite, supernova, or deep sky object shown in the rendering.
        Parameters:
        objName - Name of the object.
        objType - Type of object. Constants defined in this class.
        Returns:
        Object with the ephemeris. For some situations only certain fields of the object take sense, like name, RA, DEC, rise, set, transit, azimuth, elevation, and maybe some other. If the object name is not found null is returned.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the object type is set to an invalid value, like stars, planets, or any other unrecognized value.

        public java.lang.String getStarProperName(java.lang.String catalogName)
                                   throws JPARSECException
        Returns the proper name of a star given its catalogue name.
        Parameters:
        catalogName - Catalogue name.
        Returns:
        Proper name, or null if the star has no proper name.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • searchObject

        public LocationElement searchObject(java.lang.String s)

        Parameters:
        s - Object name.
        Returns:
        Equatorial coordinates, or null if not found.

        Equatorial coordinates, or null if not found.

      • searchDeepSkyObjectJ2000

        public static LocationElement searchDeepSkyObjectJ2000(java.lang.String obj_name)
                                                throws JPARSECException

        Throws:

      • searchDeepSkyObjectJ2000

        public static java.lang.String[] searchDeepSkyObjectJ2000(double mag)
                                                   throws JPARSECException
        Returns all deep sky objects brighter than certain magnitude.
        Parameters:
        mag - Limiting magnitude, or -1 to return all.
        Returns:
        An array containing the following fields separated by a comma: Name, second name, RA, DEC (rad), mag, max size, min size (deg), type, PA, comments.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the method fails.

      • queryUCAC

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> queryUCAC(LocationElement loc0J2000,
                                              double fieldDeg,
                                              double maglim,
                                              int timeout,
                                              TimeElement time,
                                              ObserverElement obs,
                                              EphemerisElement peph)
                                                       throws JPARSECException
        Returns all stars around a given sky location between magnitudes 9.5 and a given limiting magnitude, using UCAC4 catalog.
        Parameters:
        loc0J2000 - The J2000 equatorial location of the position.
        fieldDeg - The field of view in degrees.
        maglim - The limiting magnitude, between 10 and 16.
        timeout - Timeout for the query in s.
        time - Time object.
        obs - Observer object.
        peph - Ephemeris object.
        Returns:
        The list of stars, including for each string the apparent RA, DEC, and magnitude. Column separator is a blank space. RA and DEC are given in radians. Stars are sorted by magnitude.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • precalculateStarsAndDSO

        public void precalculateStarsAndDSO(TimeElement time,
                           boolean stars,
                           boolean dso)
                             throws JPARSECException
        Precalculate stars so that the update in the next rendering will be faster. This method should be called from another thread during sky dragging, for instance. It is used for Android. Just before rendering, the method setPrecalculatedStarsAndDSO() should be called, and the date for the new rendering should be the one set here.
        Parameters:
        time - The new date to precalculate stars.
        stars - True to precalculate stars.
        dso - True to precalculate deep sky objects.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • setPrecalculatedStarsAndDSO

        public void setPrecalculatedStarsAndDSO()
        Sets the previously precalculated stars as the default stars object.
